html:
2025-0785
2025-11-06TCAeronautics ActRegulations Amending the Canadian Aviation Regulations (ICAO-related Amendments)Regulations Amending the Canadian Aviation Regulations (ICAO-related Amendments) in order to (1) amend the medical examination framework to ensure foreign medical examiners have appropriate credentials and oversight; (2) introduce requirements for certain documents to be carried on board the aircraft (such as radio station licence and noise certification data); (3) introduce a requirement in the Canadian Aviation Regulations for subpart 703 (Air Taxi) operators to have facilities for ground and flight training programs; (4) align regulatory terminology with that used by International Civil Aviation Organization; (5) align the crew member interference levels with international partners; (6) introduce requirements for pilots to read back certain safety information and to inform which Automatic Terminal Information Service message they received to air traffic services to ensure they can manage air traffic flow; (7) clarify pilot-in-command authority and responsibility with respect to aircraft operations; and (8) correct editorial errors introduced as a result of previous amendments to this regulations.Registration: SOR/2025-0226 Publication Date: 2025-11-19
subject: Regulations Amending the Canadian Aviation Regulations (ICAO-related Amendments)
precis: Regulations Amending the Canadian Aviation Regulations (ICAO-related Amendments) in order to (1) amend the medical examination framework to ensure foreign medical examiners have appropriate credentials and oversight; (2) introduce requirements for certain documents to be carried on board the aircraft (such as radio station licence and noise certification data); (3) introduce a requirement in the Canadian Aviation Regulations for subpart 703 (Air Taxi) operators to have facilities for ground and flight training programs; (4) align regulatory terminology with that used by International Civil Aviation Organization; (5) align the crew member interference levels with international partners; (6) introduce requirements for pilots to read back certain safety information and to inform which Automatic Terminal Information Service message they received to air traffic services to ensure they can manage air traffic flow; (7) clarify pilot-in-command authority and responsibility with respect to aircraft operations; and (8) correct editorial errors introduced as a result of previous amendments to this regulations.
